message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest an inflammatory muscle disease, and the elevations in leukocyte count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and creatine kinase concentration are consistent with this. Sarcolemmal MHC-I overexpression with CD8+ lymphocytic infiltration is the hallmark histologic finding for dermatomyositis, which is a type of inflammatory myopathy. Option A describes findings in necrotizing myopathy, Option C describes changes seen in disuse atrophy, and Option D describes findings in polymyositis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, along with the elevations in leukocyte count, ESR, and creatine kinase concentration, suggest that the most likely diagnosis is polymyositis. In polymyositis, there is sarcolemmal MHC-I overexpression with CD8+ lymphocytic infiltration, which is most likely to be seen on histological evaluation of a biopsy specimen of the deltoid muscle. Option A describes muscle fiber necrosis with rare inflammatory cells, which is not typical of polymyositis. Option C describes changes in muscle fiber type, which are not typically seen in polymyositis. Option D describes perimysial inflammation with perivascular CD4+ T lymphocytic infiltration, which is more typical of dermatomyositis than polymyositis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the elevations in leukocyte count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and creatine kinase concentration, suggest the patient has inflammatory myopathy. The most common form of inflammatory myopathy is polymyositis, which presents with proximal muscle weakness, elevated muscle enzymes, and lymphocytic infiltration in muscle biopsy. Sarcolemmal MHC-I overexpression with CD8+ lymphocytic infiltration is the most common finding on muscle biopsy in patients with polymyositis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory results suggest a diagnosis of polymyositis. Histological evaluation of a biopsy specimen of the deltoid muscle in polymyositis will show MHC-I overexpression and CD8+ T lymphocytic infiltration. Therefore, the correct answer is (B). Muscle fiber necrosis with rare inflammatory cells is seen in dermatomyositis. Relative atrophy of type II muscle fibers with hypertrophy of type I muscle fibers is seen in disuse atrophy. Perimysial inflammation with perivascular CD4+ T lymphocytic infiltration is seen in inclusion body myositis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings suggest muscle weakness with signs of inflammation, which is common in cases of autoimmune myopathies. Sarcolemmal MHC-I overexpression with CD8+ lymphocytic infiltration is a characteristic finding in polymyositis and inclusion body myositis, two types of autoimmune myopathies. Option A is not consistent with muscle weakness and inflammation, and options C and D do not fit the pattern seen in autoimmune myopathies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest inflammatory myopathy, with the most likely subtype being polymyositis. This is characterized by overexpression of major histocompatibility complex class I molecules on skeletal muscle fibers and CD8+ T lymphocyte infiltration, as described in option B. Option A describes muscle fiber necrosis, which is not typical of polymyositis. Option C describes a pattern of muscle fiber atrophy that is seen in type II fiber atrophy, which is more typical of denervation or disuse atrophy. Option D describes perimysial inflammation, which can be seen in dermatomyositis but is not typically seen in polymyositis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including muscular weakness and elevation of creatine kinase concentration, suggest that she may have an autoimmune disease affecting the muscle. Sarcolemmal MHC-I overexpression with CD8+ lymphocytic infiltration is characteristic of polymyositis or inclusion body myositis. The other options are not consistent with this disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory studies suggest a diagnosis of polymyositis, which is characterized by sarcolemmal MHC-I overexpression and CD8+ lymphocytic infiltration on histological evaluation of muscle biopsy. Option A describes muscle fiber necrosis without inflammation, which is seen in muscular dystrophies. Option C describes type II muscle fiber atrophy and type I hypertrophy, which is seen in some types of myopathies. Option D describes perimysial inflammation with perivascular CD4+ T lymphocytic infiltration, which is seen in dermatomyositis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a diagnosis of dermatomyositis, which is associated with sarcolemmal MHC-I overexpression with CD8+ lymphocytic infiltration. The other options are not associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest an inflammatory myopathy, and the elevated creatine kinase and leukocyte count support this. The muscle weakness location suggests an immune-mediated myopathy such as polymyositis or dermatomyositis. In dermatomyositis, sarcolemmal MHC-I overexpression with CD8+ lymphocytic infiltration is commonly seen on histological evaluation.
